messages.text: I spend time since returning to Toledo setting up economy and other things. Some things have advanced the timeline. We are in late summer and I want to set a few things in motion still.

**Current Date:** Late Summer 1435 (the player says some things have advanced the timeline)

**Location:** Toledo

**Key Situation Points:**

1. **Royal Family:**
   - Juan II of Castile (the player character)
   - Lucia d'Este (second wife, married December 1433, after Isabel died in childbirth)
   - Fernando (Juan's son, born August/September 1433, now ~14 months when they returned to Toledo, so now ~2 years old by late summer 1435)
   - Catalina (nearly 3 in early 1435, now closer to 3.5 years)
   - Bianca (daughter with Lucia, born September 14, 1434 in Naples, now about 1 year old)

2. **Treasury Position (End 1434):**
   - Treasury: 545,987 florins
   - Naval Reserve: 200,000 florins (committed, not spent)
   - Available Treasury: 345,987 florins
   - Annual revenue: 371,594 florins
   - Annual expenses: ~197,430 florins

3. **Key Ongoing Initiatives:**
   - Junta de Manufacturas established (overseeing industrial development)
   - Economic Development Plan in execution (leather, salt/fish, silk, wool, goats, infrastructure)
   - 40,000 florins/year infrastructure program (Year 1 of 5)
   - Intelligence network established under Isaac de Baeza
   - Inquisition preparation under Torquemada
   - Demetrios Komnenos recruited as shadow guardian (en route from Venice)
   - Meeting with Sultan Murad II scheduled for Spring 1435 at Tenedos
   - Admiral from Alfonso V requested (not yet arrived)
   - 200,000 florins reserved for naval expansion
   
I'm making significant progress in Constantinople, with a robust military presence and settlement strategy. My martial skills are improving, focusing on poleaxe and lance techniques. The potential meeting with Sultan Murad II remains a critical diplomatic opportunity, though its status is still uncertain.

Several pending matters require attention: the Admiral's arrival from Aragon, integrating Demetrios Komnenos, reviewing Morocco mission outcomes, and coordinating foreign manufacturing experts. These elements will shape strategic developments in the coming months.

Now I have the full picture. Let me provide a concise introduction.

Chapter 2.30 — Late Summer 1435

Toledo, Kingdom of Castile

The months since your return to Toledo have been consumed by the patient work of building. While Lucia tends the nursery—Fernando now walks with determined purpose, Catalina chatters endlessly to her new Italian aunts, and Bianca's first teeth have emerged—you have held councils, signed charters, and set in motion the machinery of economic transformation.

The kingdom's coffers remain healthy. Your treasury stands near 545,000 florins, with 200,000 reserved for the naval expansion that awaits only an admiral's direction. Diego de Daza's first year of infrastructure investment is underway: drove roads are being surveyed, bridges assessed, watering points catalogued by the Mesta and the goatherds alike.

Your shadow capabilities are taking shape. Isaac de Baeza has established listening posts in Venice, Rome, and Naples. Demetrios Komnenos arrived from Venice some months past—a haunted man with watchful eyes who now shadows Lucia and the children with the silent focus of one who has finally found something worth protecting. Tomás de Cuenca serves as court physician, his other skills known only to you.

The manufacturing councils have met. The leather guild of Córdoba is expanding; Sevillian fishermen are learning their new vessels; Granada's silk looms multiply. The Junta de Manufacturas coordinates what was once disconnected.

Constantinople thrives beyond all expectation. Reports indicate the settlement campaign has drawn thousands of Latin families eastward. The Military Orders establish their commanderies. Emperor John VIII has reason for cautious hope.

Spring has passed. The meeting at Tenedos with Sultan Murad II—that fateful conversation you arranged through Hamza Bey—lies in the past now, its consequences still unfolding. The Admiral from Aragon, whom you requested from Alfonso V, should be arriving any day.

The Dominicans prepare their facilities in Granada. Fray Tomás de Torquemada awaits only the papal mandate to begin his work.

The late summer sun beats down on Toledo's stones. What matters do you wish to set in motion before the seasons turn?
I send for the masters of the military orders to come to me immediately. When they arrive a few weeks later, I meet them.

You're right—my apologies for the timeline error. We are in late summer 1434, with the Tenedos meeting scheduled for Spring 1435.

The Masters Arrive

Toledo, Late September 1434

The summons went out by swift courier to the three great Military Orders—Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara. Each Master received the same message: Come to Toledo at once. The King commands your presence on a matter of the highest importance.

Three weeks later, they stand before you in the council chamber of the Alcázar.

Don Rodrigo Manrique, Master of Santiago, is a weathered warrior in his fifties with the bearing of a man who has spent more nights in campaign tents than palace beds. His Order is the largest and wealthiest, its holdings stretching across Castile and Portugal.

Don García López de Padilla, Master of Calatrava, you know well—he coordinated the fortress commanders during the Granada campaign and organized the Te Deum ceremony. A steady, competent administrator as much as a soldier.

Don Gutierre de Sotomayor, Master of Alcántara, is the youngest of the three, having risen to his position only recently. His Order guards the Portuguese frontier and holds lands in Extremadura.

All three wear the white mantles of their respective Orders, crosses prominent. They have traveled far and fast at your command, and their expressions show a mixture of curiosity and wariness. The 5,000 florins you granted each Order for their "Eastern mission" has not been forgotten—nor has the transformation you have already wrought upon their world.

Don Rodrigo speaks first, as senior among them: "Your Majesty summoned us with urgency. We are here. How may the Orders serve the Crown?"

You're right—Don Gutierre de Sotomayor commands the Military Order forces in Constantinople. Let me correct that.

The Masters Arrive

Toledo, Late September 1434

Three weeks after your summons, two Masters and one representative stand before you in the council chamber of the Alcázar.

Don Rodrigo Manrique, Master of Santiago, is a weathered warrior in his fifties with the bearing of a man who has spent more nights in campaign tents than palace beds. His Order is the largest and wealthiest, its holdings stretching across Castile and Portugal.

Don García López de Padilla, Master of Calatrava, you know well—he coordinated the fortress commanders during the Granada campaign and organized the Te Deum ceremony. A steady, competent administrator as much as a soldier.

Don Fernando de Solís, Commander of Alcántara's Castilian holdings, represents his Order in Master Sotomayor's absence. A solid knight in his forties, he carries the weight of speaking for an Order whose Master leads a thousand men on the far side of the Mediterranean.

All three wear the white mantles of their respective Orders, crosses prominent. They have traveled far and fast at your command, and their expressions show a mixture of curiosity and wariness. The 5,000 florins you granted each Order for their "Eastern mission" has not been forgotten—nor has the transformation you have already wrought upon their world.

Don Rodrigo speaks first, as senior among them: "Your Majesty summoned us with urgency. We are here. How may the Orders serve the Crown?"

Lords, I shall come to business immediately. I want Constantinople populated. We have done this before with conquered territories. Right now, there lies enormous opportunity in the east. A new purpose for the orders. A new crusade. A new reconquista. I want to learn how we can arrange this.


Also I want to learn how the reinforcement of the current watch on the walls is going since I have ordered you to sail another 300 soldiers to the city this spring.

**Don Rodrigo Manrique (Master of Santiago):**
- What does he want? Santiago is the wealthiest order. They have extensive holdings in Castile. Moving operations to the East means... what exactly? Abandoning their Spanish holdings? Splitting their forces? He'll want to know what this means for their existing properties and incomes.
- What won't he say? He probably won't openly say he's worried about losing influence in Castile, or that the Eastern mission feels like exile.
- What has he seen? Granada conquered. The Orders' traditional purpose (Reconquista) complete. Juan's growing power. The 5,000 florins grant. The settlement campaign in Constantinople showing extraordinary success (roll of 99).

**Don García López de Padilla (Master of Calatrava):**
- What does he want? Calatrava controls the Almadén mercury mines. They have significant holdings. Similar concerns to Santiago.
- What won't he say? Similar reservations.
- What has he seen? He worked closely with Juan during Granada, so he knows Juan's style. He's reliable.

**Don Fernando de Solís (Commander representing Alcántara):**
- What does he want? He's in an awkward position - his Master is already in Constantinople. He probably wants to know what resources he's supposed to send, and whether the Order's Castilian holdings will be maintained.
- What won't he say? He can't make major commitments without his Master's approval.
- What has he seen? His Order is already most committed to the Eastern mission.

Now, regarding the 300 soldiers - I need to check what was actually ordered. Let me think about what I found in the project files...

The military expansion is significant. Juan has increased troop presence to 1,000 soldiers, with 300 additional troops joining the existing force. The settlement campaign has been remarkably successful, suggesting a strategic vision for establishing a strong Castilian presence in Constantinople. The masters will be weighing the potential benefits against the risks of committing resources to this eastern venture.

Their key concerns range from practical governance challenges to financial implications. They'll seek clarity on security responsibilities, territorial management, and the potential impact on existing Spanish territories. The interaction with the Byzantine government will be a critical point of discussion, as will the funding mechanism for this ambitious resettlement and military deployment strategy.

The three men exchange glances. Don Rodrigo's weathered face remains composed, but you can see the calculation behind his eyes. Don García nods slowly, as if he expected something of this nature. Don Fernando de Solís shifts slightly—he is the one in the most awkward position, representing an Order whose Master already stands on Constantinople's walls.

Don García speaks first to the practical matter: "The three hundred reinforcements sailed from Valencia in April, Your Majesty, with Aragonese transport ships King Alfonso provided. They should have reached Constantinople by midsummer. We have had no report of disaster, so we must assume they arrived safely." He pauses. "We await word from Master Sotomayor, but communications from the East are... slow."

Don Rodrigo clears his throat and addresses the larger question. His tone is respectful but measured.

"Your Majesty speaks of populating Constantinople as we populated the lands taken from the Moors. Santiago remembers well how this was done—we were granted territories, we brought settlers, we built commanderies and churches, we made wilderness into Christendom." He folds his hands. "But Constantinople is not an empty frontier. It is an ancient city with an Emperor, a Patriarch, laws and customs a thousand years old. The Greeks..."

He chooses his words carefully.

"The Greeks have their own way of things. What role does Your Majesty envision for the Orders in this... new Reconquista? Are we to hold lands granted by Emperor John? Recruit Castilian families to settle in Byzantine territory? Defend walls that Greek soldiers have defended for centuries?"

Don Fernando speaks up, perhaps emboldened by the fact that his Order is already committed: "Master Sotomayor writes that the settlement proclamation has drawn great interest. Families are coming. But he notes that quarters are cramped, that the Greeks watch the Latins with... wariness. A thousand of our men already strain the city's patience. What numbers does Your Majesty contemplate?"

I find it hard to believe that accomodations are cramped. The city housed half a million easily. There are now living 40.000 souls there. Housing is not the problem. And I have established with the emperor a new law that is fair to both latins and greeks. We can build churches and all. There are living millions of christians in my kingdom. If only a small amount want to migrate to the new fronties, we will outnumber the greeks. This is not a goal on itself, I do not seek to dominate the Greeks, but we will be able to bring our own culture and not be a minority. The city is growing rapidly and the announcements are well-recieved. I want to send even more men there. Surely the knights of Santiago are suited to exactly this purpose no? And I can grant any decree both as defensor and as king should this be needed.

Juan is pointing out:
1. Constantinople once held 500,000, now only 40,000 - housing is abundant
2. He has established fair laws (the Charter of Latin Courts, etc.)
3. Millions of Christians in Castile - even small migration would outnumber Greeks
4. He doesn't seek to dominate Greeks, just establish a Latin presence
5. The settlement campaign is working well
6. He can grant decrees as both Defensor Romaniae and King of Castile
7. Santiago's purpose is exactly this kind of frontier work

The Masters need to respond realistically. What are their concerns?

Don Rodrigo of Santiago specifically:
- Santiago is the largest, wealthiest order
- Their holdings are in Castile and Portugal
- They've just seen Granada conquered - their traditional purpose fulfilled
- Moving east means abandoning comfortable Spanish holdings for uncertain Eastern adventure
- But Juan has a point - this IS what they were founded for

What would realistic concerns be?
1. Logistics - how do we transport settlers?
2. Finances - who pays for this?
3. Governance - what lands/rights will the Orders receive?
4. Purpose - are we defending, settling, or both?
5. Ottoman threat - we're putting our men in the path of the Turk
6. Competition with Greeks - will this cause friction?
7. Their own institutional interests - do they give up Spanish holdings?

Don Rodrigo wouldn't be hostile - Juan has won the Granada crusade, he's clearly blessed by God and successful. But he would want to understand the practical arrangements. This is a negotiation about terms, not about whether to obey the King.

Let me have them respond thoughtfully, acknowledging Juan's points while pressing for practical details. They're not refusing - they're trying to understand what this means for their Orders.

Don Rodrigo inclines his head, acknowledging your points. The defensive note in his earlier words softens—you have answered his concerns directly, and he is too experienced a man to argue against facts.

"Your Majesty speaks truly. I had not considered the scale of the emptiness." He strokes his beard thoughtfully. "A city built for half a million, holding forty thousand. There is room for a kingdom within those walls."

Don García leans forward, his administrator's mind already working. "The settlement proclamation—I have read the terms. Generous. Land grants, tax relief, protection under Latin law while respecting Greek customs. If this is being well-received, as Your Majesty says, then the Orders could serve as... anchors. Commanderies that settlers cluster around, as they did in Extremadura and La Mancha."

Don Fernando nods cautiously. "Master Sotomayor's letters speak of the walls, the watches, the drills with Greek soldiers. But he has said little of settlement work. If Your Majesty wishes the Orders to take on this second role—not merely defending Constantinople but populating it—then we must discuss practical matters."

Don Rodrigo raises a hand, ticking off fingers: "First, transport. Moving a thousand knights is one thing. Moving families—wives, children, livestock, tools, seed grain—requires ships we do not have. Second, land grants. Your Majesty holds authority as Defensor, but what territories can you promise? Inside the walls? The Thracian hinterland? Third..."

He pauses, meeting your eyes directly.

"Third, the Turk. We are not fools, Your Majesty. We know why you reinforce those walls. Settlers will ask: are we going to a new home, or to a siege? What do we tell them?"

I will arrange the transport. Dont worry. I will hire it or commandeer it. And we have the Castillian fleet itself we can use for this purpose.


Everyone moving to the city will be provided with one house. It may have been abandoned for some time so they will have to repair it, but the land and whatever remains of the structure is theirs.


And dont worry about the sultan. We are reinforcing the strongest and best defended city in the world. The orders protect it, I protect it and christ protects it. Fighting for it and manning it's walls is an act of faith.

Juan is making a passionate pitch to the Military Order masters about expanding settlement in Constantinople. He's addressing their concerns about transport, housing, and the Ottoman threat. Let me think about how these men would realistically respond.

Don Rodrigo Manrique is the senior master - Santiago is the largest and wealthiest order. He's a practical man who has seen many campaigns. He'll be weighing the costs and benefits to his Order.

Don García López de Padilla of Calatrava is the administrator type - he organized the Te Deum, he's steady and competent. He'll be thinking about logistics.

Don Fernando de Solís is representing Alcántara in Sotomayor's absence - he's in an awkward position because his Order is already committed to Constantinople.

Juan's pitch is compelling but the Masters will have concerns:
1. This is a major commitment of resources and men
2. The Orders derive their wealth and power from their Spanish lands - moving resources east means less influence at home
3. The Ottoman threat is real - Juan's confidence is inspiring but they know wars are uncertain
4. What's in it for the Orders specifically? New lands, new purpose, yes, but also new risks

They should acknowledge Juan's points while pressing for specifics about what he actually wants from them - numbers, timelines, what territories, what authority the Orders would have.

They shouldn't be hostile - Juan has been generous and successful. But they should be cautious businessmen protecting their Orders' interests. Low rolls don't apply here since there's no roll - this is just a conversation about logistics and commitment.

Let me write their response - they should be warming to the idea but still seeking concrete details about what Juan actually wants from them.

The invocation of faith lands differently with each man. Don Fernando crosses himself reflexively—his Order already stands on those walls, and the reminder that their work is holy service visibly steadies him. Don García nods with the pragmatic acceptance of a man who has heard many such speeches but recognizes when one is backed by genuine conviction and resources.

Don Rodrigo studies you for a long moment. Whatever skepticism he carried into this chamber is fading. You have answered his practical objections and offered something his Order has lacked since Granada fell: purpose.

"Santiago was founded to fight the Moor," he says slowly. "For three centuries, that was our reason for being. When Granada fell, men asked—what now? Guard empty frontiers? Grow fat on our estates?" He shakes his head. "Your Majesty offers us a new enemy, a new frontier, a new purpose. This is... not unwelcome."

Don García speaks up: "Calatrava holds lands in La Mancha that have been peaceful for a generation. Our younger knights grow restless. The chance to build something—commanderies in the East, a new chapter of our Order's history—this would draw volunteers, not conscripts."

Don Fernando adds quietly: "Master Sotomayor already speaks of Alcántara's future being written on Byzantine stone rather than Portuguese borders."

Don Rodrigo leans forward, his tone shifting from philosophical to practical.

"Very well, Your Majesty. You have transport, you have housing, you have faith. Tell us what you want. How many knights from each Order? How many settler families do you wish us to recruit from our lands? What timeline? And—" he glances at his peers, "—what authority will the Orders hold in Constantinople? Will we answer to Master Sotomayor? To Emperor John? To Your Majesty directly?"

You will answer to me. But my highest commander in the city is Sotomayor right now. Everyone answers to me in the city. That is the benefit of being the defensor.


How many? As much as possible. I hope that in years we bring the city back to it's former population level. 500.000 citizens. This will take a while but the best locations, the best claims are established now. We are limited by many factors. How many families could we theoretically move if transport with ships would be no factor?

The Military Orders (Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara) held extensive territories across Castile, with tenant farmers, villages, and towns under their jurisdiction. They could:
1. Recruit from their own territories (peasants, craftsmen, minor nobility)
2. Use their networks and reputation to attract volunteers from outside their lands
3. Organize the logistics of gathering people, their possessions, etc.

But there are limiting factors beyond just ships:
- Willingness of people to uproot their lives
- The Orders' administrative capacity
- The need to not depopulate their own lands too much
- Seasonal considerations (harvests, etc.)
- The time needed to organize such movements

Let me have the Masters give a realistic assessment. They should be thoughtful about this - they know their lands and people.

Don Rodrigo of Santiago would have the largest capacity as the wealthiest Order.
Don García of Calatrava would give a measured, administrative response.
Don Fernando would speak more tentatively since he's not the Master.

I should have them discuss practical realities:
- How many families per year could realistically be organized?
- What kinds of people would be willing to go?
- What would motivate settlers?

They shouldn't just give a single number - this is a complex question that requires discussion. And they should be realistic, not just agreeable. Moving thousands of families is a massive undertaking.

The three men fall silent for a moment. This is not a question any of them has considered in such terms before. Don Rodrigo turns to Don García, who has the most administrative experience among them.

Don García pulls at his chin, calculating. "Your Majesty asks us to think without limits, but there are limits beyond ships. Willingness. Organization. The harvest cycle—no peasant family will leave between planting and reaping."

He begins thinking aloud: "Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara together hold perhaps... six hundred towns and villages across Castile, León, and Extremadura. Some prosperous, some poor. The poor are more willing to move—they have less to lose. A young second son with no inheritance, a widow with children, a craftsman whose guild has no room for him..."

Don Rodrigo picks up the thread: "From Santiago's lands alone, if we preached this as a crusade—land, housing, purpose, salvation—we might find five hundred families in a good year who would take the Cross and go East. Perhaps more if the terms are generous and the reports from early settlers are favorable."

"Calatrava, perhaps three hundred," Don García adds. "Our territories are smaller."

Don Fernando speaks carefully: "Alcántara is the smallest of the three. Two hundred families, perhaps. But Master Sotomayor's presence in Constantinople itself is an advantage—letters home from knights already there carry weight."

Don Rodrigo summarizes: "A thousand families per year, perhaps. More if Your Majesty extends recruitment beyond Order lands to all of Castile. Fewer if the news from the East turns sour." He pauses. "That is four or five thousand souls annually. To reach five hundred thousand..."

He leaves the arithmetic unspoken.

I will allow you to include recruitment across Castille. Why would I not? And I will encourage the knights of Rhodes to do the same fromm their estates and commanderies in Aragon as well.


Five thousand souls are a lot. Let me first see how many ships I can actually arrange. I want them to travel is decent accomodation as well. But it is encouraging that you can find settlers in such numbers.


For now, maybe just see and count those who are willing to go. I will see what ships I can find, the spring 1435 we will sail east with the first settlers.

The Masters should respond practically - they need to organize a census of willing settlers, which takes time and resources. They might have questions about:
- Who pays for the survey/recruitment effort?
- What exactly should they promise potential settlers?
- How to coordinate across three Orders plus all of Castile?
- The spring 1435 timeline - is that realistic?

Don Rodrigo as the senior should probably take the lead on organizing this. Don García is the administrator. Don Fernando needs to communicate with Sotomayor.

I should have them accept the task, ask practical clarifying questions, and set things in motion. This is a "yes, and here's what we need to do it" response rather than resistance - the player has addressed their concerns and this is genuinely a good opportunity for the Orders.

Don Rodrigo nods slowly, and you can see something shift in his bearing—the wariness of a subordinate being given orders transforming into the energy of a commander given a mission.

"It will be done, Your Majesty. We will send riders to every commandery, every town under our jurisdiction. The message will be clear: land, housing, and holy purpose in the East. Those willing to take the Cross and settle, make yourselves known."

Don García is already thinking through the logistics. "We should use a common standard for the count—heads of household, with numbers of family members, their trades if they have them. A blacksmith is worth more to a new settlement than ten peasants with nothing but strong backs." He glances at you. "Does Your Majesty wish us to coordinate this survey, or shall we each report separately?"

"Coordinate," Don Rodrigo answers before you can speak, then catches himself. "That is—if Your Majesty permits. One combined report will be more useful than three partial ones."

Don Fernando speaks up: "I will write to Master Sotomayor immediately. He should know settlers are coming in spring. And he can send back word of what trades are most needed—perhaps there are skills Constantinople lacks that we should prioritize."

Don Rodrigo turns back to you. "Spring 1435. That gives us six months to count, to preach, to prepare. It is enough." He pauses. "What of the Knights of Rhodes, Your Majesty? Shall we approach them, or will you write to their Grand Master yourself?"

I will write their grandmaster myself.


Finally, I have granted the orders ports in Grenada. To build up your own naval strength. I understand I make much demand on the orders, but I am curious how this is coming along.


Draft a d100 table to see how developed the order's fleets are.

SUCCESS FACTORS:
- The Orders received 5,000 florins each (15,000 total) for their "Eastern mission"
- They were granted ports in Granada
- They have motivation - their new purpose is in the East
- The Granada conquest happened in late 1432, so they've had about 2 years
- The Orders have wealth from their extensive landholdings
- They have experience organizing large-scale operations

FAILURE FACTORS:
- The Military Orders are traditionally LAND-based forces - cavalry, infantry, fortresses
- Naval expertise is completely different from their traditional skills
- Shipbuilding takes specialized craftsmen they don't have
- Granada's ports would need development after the conquest
- 2 years is not very long to build a naval tradition from scratch
- Castile itself lacks significant naval capacity (hence needing an Admiral from Aragon)
- The Orders' primary focus has been Constantinople garrison duty, not shipbuilding
- 5,000 florins each is a decent sum but not enormous for naval construction
- They would need to hire foreign shipwrights and sailors

This is a situation where the Orders have been given a task outside their core competency. They're warriors and administrators of land, not sailors. Even with money and motivation, building a fleet from nothing is a multi-year undertaking that requires expertise they don't have.

I should create a table that reflects this reality - probably weighted toward modest or limited progress, with the possibility of either surprising success (if they hired good people) or near-failure (if they didn't prioritize it or didn't know how to begin).

Let me draft:

1-10: Virtually Nothing
The Orders focused entirely on the Constantinople garrison. Ports remain undeveloped, no ships constructed. Perhaps some preliminary surveys or plans, but no actual progress.
 
The Orders are making tentative steps into naval development, but their progress is painfully slow. They've managed to acquire a few small vessels through purchase, likely relying on existing maritime traders or neighboring kingdoms. The ports remain largely untouched, with minimal infrastructure improvements. Their lack of naval expertise is evident - they're essentially waiting for guidance, unsure how to proceed with their maritime responsibilities. The shipbuilding process hasn't truly begun, reflecting their traditional land-based military background.

At this stage, they've barely scratched the surface of naval capability. One Order might have shown slightly more initiative, perhaps hiring a local shipwright or beginning preliminary discussions about vessel construction. However, the overall effort remains minimal, demonstrating their significant learning curve in maritime endeavors.

The development is characterized by uncertainty and hesitation. They understand the strategic importance of naval power but lack the practical knowledge to transform their mandate into actual maritime strength. Their approach is more reactive than proactive, waiting for clear direction or external expertise to guide their naval transformation. They've built a credible naval capability, starting from minimal maritime experience. The progression shows strategic investment and gradual skill development, with realistic potential for naval growth balanced against inherent challenges.

Don Rodrigo exchanges a glance with Don García. The question touches on something they have clearly discussed amongst themselves—and perhaps worried over.

"Your Majesty granted us Almería, Almuñécar, and Adra," Don García says carefully. "We have... begun."

The hesitation in his voice suggests the answer may not be entirely satisfactory. Let me consider the factors:

SUCCESS FACTORS:

5,000 florins granted to each Order for their Eastern mission

Ports in Granada awarded to develop naval capacity

Strong motivation—their new purpose requires sea transport

Nearly two years since Granada fell (late 1432)

Orders have wealth from extensive landholdings

Organizational capacity proven in the crusade

FAILURE FACTORS:

Military Orders are land forces—cavalry, fortresses, infantry

No naval tradition, expertise, or experienced sailors

Shipbuilding requires specialized craftsmen they don't possess

Granada's ports need repair after conquest and years of decline

Castile itself lacks naval capacity (hence requesting Aragonese admiral)

Primary focus has been Constantinople garrison, not shipbuilding

Two years is short for building naval tradition from nothing

Don García permits himself a small smile—the expression of a man who has better news than he feared he might.

"Almería has become our primary base, Your Majesty. The harbor was sound—the Moors maintained it well—and we have repaired the quays and warehouses." He straightens slightly. "We pooled a portion of the funds you granted and hired Valencian shipwrights. King Alfonso's subjects, men who know Mediterranean vessels."

Don Rodrigo continues: "Santiago has three galleys operational and a fourth under construction. Small vessels—forty oars each—but seaworthy. We have hired Catalan captains to train our knights in seamanship." He grimaces slightly. "It is... humbling. Men who can ride down a Moorish cavalry charge find themselves vomiting over the rails like children. But they are learning."

"Calatrava has two galleys and a larger transport vessel—a nao of perhaps eighty tons," Don García adds. "We focused on cargo capacity. Knights can fight, but settlers need ships that carry grain and livestock."

Don Fernando speaks up: "Alcántara contributed to the Almería development but has only one vessel of our own. Master Sotomayor felt our resources were better spent on the Constantinople garrison."

Don Rodrigo summarizes: "Eight vessels operational between us, Your Majesty. Two more under construction. By spring, perhaps ten or eleven. Small, but..." He shrugs. "Two years ago we had none. We had never thought of ourselves as sailors."

He meets your eyes. "It is a beginning. Not yet a fleet. But a beginning."
Could these ships be used to transport settlers? How much could they transport realistically? And how many if I commit the entire Castillian fleet to the effort as well? 4 carracks and 5 galleys?

The Military Orders have:
- 8 vessels operational (6 galleys of ~40 oars each, 1 nao of ~80 tons, 1 transport)
- By spring, 10-11 vessels

Castilian fleet:
- 4 carracks
- 5 galleys

Let me think about medieval ship capacities for transporting settlers (families with belongings, not just soldiers crammed in):

Galleys (40 oars):
